Misconception: Simple harmonic motion must involve springs
Explanation: Assumes SHM only occurs with mass-spring systems, overlooking other cases like pendulums or oscillating carts.

Misconception: Amplitude affects period in all SHM
Explanation: Fails to realize that for ideal SHM (like mass-spring or small-angle pendulum), period is independent of amplitude.

Misconception: SHM requires a net constant force
Explanation: Misunderstands that SHM involves a restoring force proportional to displacement, not a constant net force.

Misconception: The object stops at equilibrium in SHM
Explanation: Thinks the motion ends when the object reaches equilibrium, not recognizing SHM continues through it.
Confuses SHM with uniform acceleration, not realizing that acceleration in SHM varies with position.

Misconception: Velocity and acceleration peak at the same time
Explanation: Fails to understand that in SHM, velocity is zero when acceleration is maximum, and vice versa.

Misconception: Only mass affects motion in SHM
Explanation: Ignores that both spring constant or pendulum length (depending on system) influence the period of oscillation.
